segment.source: Diagnosing Windows Runtime Component error conditions
segment.target: Diagnosing Windows Runtime Component error conditions

segment.source: This article provides additional information about restrictions on Windows Runtime Components written with managed code.
segment.target: This article provides additional information about restrictions on Windows Runtime Components written with managed code.

segment.source: Diagnosing Windows Runtime Component error conditions
segment.target: Diagnosing Windows Runtime Component error conditions

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]

segment.source: This article provides additional information about restrictions on Windows Runtime Components written with managed code.
segment.target: This article provides additional information about restrictions on Windows Runtime Components written with managed code.

segment.source: It expands on the information that is provided in error messages from Winmdexp.exe (Windows Runtime Metadata Export Tool), and complements the information on restrictions that is provided in Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic.
segment.target: It expands on the information that is provided in error messages from Winmdexp.exe (Windows Runtime Metadata Export Tool), and complements the information on restrictions that is provided in Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic.

segment.source: This article doesn’t cover all errors.
segment.target: This article doesn’t cover all errors.

segment.source: The errors discussed here are grouped by general category, and each category includes a table of associated error messages.
segment.target: The errors discussed here are grouped by general category, and each category includes a table of associated error messages.

segment.source: Search for message text (omitting specific values for placeholders) or for message number.
segment.target: Search for message text (omitting specific values for placeholders) or for message number.

segment.source: If you don’t find the information you need here, please help us improve the documentation by using the feedback button at the end of this article.
segment.target: If you don’t find the information you need here, please help us improve the documentation by using the feedback button at the end of this article.

segment.source: Include the error message.
segment.target: Include the error message.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can file a bug at the Microsoft Connect website.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can file a bug at the Microsoft Connect website.

segment.source: Error message for implementing async interface provides incorrect type
segment.target: Error message for implementing async interface provides incorrect type

segment.source: Managed Windows Runtime Components cannot implement the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) interfaces that represent asynchronous actions or operations (IAsyncAction, IAsyncActionWithProgressTProgress, IAsyncOperationTResult, or IAsyncOperationWithProgressTResult, TProgress).
segment.target: Managed Windows Runtime Components cannot implement the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) interfaces that represent asynchronous actions or operations (IAsyncAction, IAsyncActionWithProgressTProgress, IAsyncOperationTResult, or IAsyncOperationWithProgressTResult, TProgress).

segment.source: Instead, the .NET Framework provides the AsyncInfo class for generating async operations in Windows Runtime Components.
segment.target: Instead, the .NET Framework provides the AsyncInfo class for generating async operations in Windows Runtime Components.

segment.source: The error message that Winmdexp.exe displays when you try to implement an async interface incorrectly refers to this class by its former name, AsyncInfoFactory.
segment.target: The error message that Winmdexp.exe displays when you try to implement an async interface incorrectly refers to this class by its former name, AsyncInfoFactory.

segment.source: The .NET Framework no longer includes the AsyncInfoFactory class.
segment.target: The .NET Framework no longer includes the AsyncInfoFactory class.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1084
segment.target: WME1084

segment.source: Type '{0}' implements Windows Runtime async interface '{1}'.
segment.target: Type '{0}' implements Windows Runtime async interface '{1}'.

segment.source: Windows Runtime types cannot implement async interfaces.
segment.target: Windows Runtime types cannot implement async interfaces.

segment.source: Please use the System.Runtime.InteropServices.WindowsRuntime.AsyncInfoFactory class to generate async operations for export to Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Please use the System.Runtime.InteropServices.WindowsRuntime.AsyncInfoFactory class to generate async operations for export to Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Note The error messages that refer to the Windows Runtime use an old terminology.
segment.target: Note The error messages that refer to the Windows Runtime use an old terminology.

segment.source: This is now referred to as the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).
segment.target: This is now referred to as the Universal Windows Platform (UWP).

segment.source: For example, Windows Runtime types are now called UWP types.
segment.target: For example, Windows Runtime types are now called UWP types.

segment.source: Missing references to mscorlib.dll or System.Runtime.dll
segment.target: Missing references to mscorlib.dll or System.Runtime.dll

segment.source: This issue occurs only when you use Winmdexp.exe from the command line.
segment.target: This issue occurs only when you use Winmdexp.exe from the command line.

segment.source: We recommend that you use the /reference option to include references to both mscorlib.dll and System.Runtime.dll from the .NET Framework core reference assemblies, which are located in "%ProgramFiles(x86)%\\Reference Assemblies\\Microsoft\\Framework\\.NETCore\\v4.5" ("%ProgramFiles%\\..." on a 32-bit computer).
segment.target: We recommend that you use the /reference option to include references to both mscorlib.dll and System.Runtime.dll from the .NET Framework core reference assemblies, which are located in "%ProgramFiles(x86)%\\Reference Assemblies\\Microsoft\\Framework\\.NETCore\\v4.5" ("%ProgramFiles%\\..." on a 32-bit computer).

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1009
segment.target: WME1009

segment.source: No reference was made to mscorlib.dll.
segment.target: No reference was made to mscorlib.dll.

segment.source: A reference to this metadata file is required in order to export correctly.
segment.target: A reference to this metadata file is required in order to export correctly.

segment.source: WME1090
segment.target: WME1090

segment.source: Could not determine the core reference assembly.
segment.target: Could not determine the core reference assembly.

segment.source: Please make sure mscorlib.dll and System.Runtime.dll is referenced using the /reference switch.
segment.target: Please make sure mscorlib.dll and System.Runtime.dll is referenced using the /reference switch.

segment.source: Operator overloading is not allowed
segment.target: Operator overloading is not allowed

segment.source: In a Windows Runtime Component written in managed code, you cannot expose overloaded operators on public types.
segment.target: In a Windows Runtime Component written in managed code, you cannot expose overloaded operators on public types.

segment.source: Note In the error message, the operator is identified by its metadata name, such as op\_Addition, op\_Multiply, op\_ExclusiveOr, op\_Implicit (implicit conversion), and so on.
segment.target: Note In the error message, the operator is identified by its metadata name, such as op\_Addition, op\_Multiply, op\_ExclusiveOr, op\_Implicit (implicit conversion), and so on.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1087
segment.target: WME1087

segment.source: '{0}' is an operator overload.
segment.target: '{0}' is an operator overload.

segment.source: Managed types cannot expose operator overloads in the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Managed types cannot expose operator overloads in the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Constructors on a class have the same number of parameters
segment.target: Constructors on a class have the same number of parameters

segment.source: In the UWP, a class can have only one constructor with a given number of parameters; for example, you can't have one constructor that has a single parameter of type String and another that has a single parameter of type int (Integer in Visual Basic).
segment.target: In the UWP, a class can have only one constructor with a given number of parameters; for example, you can't have one constructor that has a single parameter of type String and another that has a single parameter of type int (Integer in Visual Basic).

segment.source: The only workaround is to use a different number of parameters for each constructor.
segment.target: The only workaround is to use a different number of parameters for each constructor.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1099
segment.target: WME1099

segment.source: Type '{0}' has multiple constructors with '{1}' argument(s).
segment.target: Type '{0}' has multiple constructors with '{1}' argument(s).

segment.source: Windows Runtime types cannot have multiple constructors with the same number of arguments.
segment.target: Windows Runtime types cannot have multiple constructors with the same number of arguments.

segment.source: Must specify a default for overloads that have the same number of parameters
segment.target: Must specify a default for overloads that have the same number of parameters

segment.source: In the UWP, overloaded methods can have the same number of parameters only if one overload is specified as the default overload.
segment.target: In the UWP, overloaded methods can have the same number of parameters only if one overload is specified as the default overload.

segment.source: See "Overloaded Methods" in Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic.
segment.target: See "Overloaded Methods" in Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1059
segment.target: WME1059

segment.source: Multiple {0}-parameter overloads of '{1}.{2}' are decorated with Windows.Foundation.Metadata.DefaultOverloadAttribute.
segment.target: Multiple {0}-parameter overloads of '{1}.{2}' are decorated with Windows.Foundation.Metadata.DefaultOverloadAttribute.

segment.source: WME1085
segment.target: WME1085

segment.source: The {0}-parameter overloads of {1}.{2} must have exactly one method specified as the default overload by decorating it with Windows.Foundation.Metadata.DefaultOverloadAttribute.
segment.target: The {0}-parameter overloads of {1}.{2} must have exactly one method specified as the default overload by decorating it with Windows.Foundation.Metadata.DefaultOverloadAttribute.

segment.source: Namespace errors and invalid names for the output file
segment.target: Namespace errors and invalid names for the output file

segment.source: In the Universal Windows Platform, all the public types in a Windows metadata (.winmd) file must be in a namespace that shares the .winmd file name, or in sub-namespaces of the file name.
segment.target: In the Universal Windows Platform, all the public types in a Windows metadata (.winmd) file must be in a namespace that shares the .winmd file name, or in sub-namespaces of the file name.

segment.source: For example, if your Visual Studio project is named A.B (that is, your Windows Runtime Component is A.B.winmd), it can contain public classes A.B.Class1 and A.B.C.Class2, but not A.Class3 (WME0006) or D.Class4 (WME1044).
segment.target: For example, if your Visual Studio project is named A.B (that is, your Windows Runtime Component is A.B.winmd), it can contain public classes A.B.Class1 and A.B.C.Class2, but not A.Class3 (WME0006) or D.Class4 (WME1044).

segment.source: Note These restrictions apply only to public types, not to private types used in your implementation.
segment.target: Note These restrictions apply only to public types, not to private types used in your implementation.

segment.source: In the case of A.Class3, you can either move Class3 to another namespace or change the name of the Windows Runtime Component to A.winmd.
segment.target: In the case of A.Class3, you can either move Class3 to another namespace or change the name of the Windows Runtime Component to A.winmd.

segment.source: Although WME0006 is a warning, you should treat it as an error.
segment.target: Although WME0006 is a warning, you should treat it as an error.

segment.source: In the previous example, code that calls A.B.winmd will be unable to locate A.Class3.
segment.target: In the previous example, code that calls A.B.winmd will be unable to locate A.Class3.

segment.source: In the case of D.Class4, no file name can contain both D.Class4 and classes in the A.B namespace, so changing the name of the Windows Runtime Component is not an option.
segment.target: In the case of D.Class4, no file name can contain both D.Class4 and classes in the A.B namespace, so changing the name of the Windows Runtime Component is not an option.

segment.source: You can either move D.Class4 to another namespace, or put it in another Windows Runtime Component.
segment.target: You can either move D.Class4 to another namespace, or put it in another Windows Runtime Component.

segment.source: The file system can't distinguish between uppercase and lowercase, so namespaces that differ by case are not allowed (WME1067).
segment.target: The file system can't distinguish between uppercase and lowercase, so namespaces that differ by case are not allowed (WME1067).

segment.source: Your component must contain at least one public sealed type (Public NotInheritable in Visual Basic).
segment.target: Your component must contain at least one public sealed type (Public NotInheritable in Visual Basic).

segment.source: If not, you will get WME1042 or WME1043, depending on whether your component contains private types.
segment.target: If not, you will get WME1042 or WME1043, depending on whether your component contains private types.

segment.source: A type in a Windows Runtime Component cannot have a name that is the same as a namespace (WME1068).
segment.target: A type in a Windows Runtime Component cannot have a name that is the same as a namespace (WME1068).

segment.source: Caution If you call Winmdexp.exe directly and don't use the /out option to specify a name for your Windows Runtime Component, Winmdexp.exe tries to generate a name that includes all the namespaces in the component.
segment.target: Caution If you call Winmdexp.exe directly and don't use the /out option to specify a name for your Windows Runtime Component, Winmdexp.exe tries to generate a name that includes all the namespaces in the component.

segment.source: Renaming namespaces can change the name of your component.
segment.target: Renaming namespaces can change the name of your component.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME0006
segment.target: WME0006

segment.source: '{0}' is not a valid winmd file name for this assembly.
segment.target: '{0}' is not a valid winmd file name for this assembly.

segment.source: All types within a Windows Metadata file must exist in a sub namespace of the namespace that is implied by the file name.
segment.target: All types within a Windows Metadata file must exist in a sub namespace of the namespace that is implied by the file name.

segment.source: Types that do not exist in such a sub namespace cannot be located at runtime.
segment.target: Types that do not exist in such a sub namespace cannot be located at runtime.

segment.source: In this assembly, the smallest common namespace that could serve as a filename is '{1}'.
segment.target: In this assembly, the smallest common namespace that could serve as a filename is '{1}'.

segment.source: WME1042
segment.target: WME1042

segment.source: Input module must contain at least one public type that is located inside a namespace.
segment.target: Input module must contain at least one public type that is located inside a namespace.

segment.source: WME1043
segment.target: WME1043

segment.source: Input module must contain at least one public type that is located inside a namespace.
segment.target: Input module must contain at least one public type that is located inside a namespace.

segment.source: The only types found inside namespaces are private.
segment.target: The only types found inside namespaces are private.

segment.source: WME1044
segment.target: WME1044

segment.source: A public type has a namespace ('{1}') that shares no common prefix with other namespaces ('{0}').
segment.target: A public type has a namespace ('{1}') that shares no common prefix with other namespaces ('{0}').

segment.source: All types within a Windows Metadata file must exist in a sub namespace of the namespace that is implied by the file name.
segment.target: All types within a Windows Metadata file must exist in a sub namespace of the namespace that is implied by the file name.

segment.source: WME1067
segment.target: WME1067

segment.source: Namespace names cannot differ only by case: '{0}', '{1}'.
segment.target: Namespace names cannot differ only by case: '{0}', '{1}'.

segment.source: WME1068
segment.target: WME1068

segment.source: Type '{0}' cannot have the same name as namespace '{1}'.
segment.target: Type '{0}' cannot have the same name as namespace '{1}'.

segment.source: Exporting types that aren't valid Universal Windows Platform types
segment.target: Exporting types that aren't valid Universal Windows Platform types

segment.source: The public interface of your component must expose only UWP types.
segment.target: The public interface of your component must expose only UWP types.

segment.source: However, the .NET Framework provides mappings for a number of commonly used types that are slightly different in the .NET Framework and the UWP.
segment.target: However, the .NET Framework provides mappings for a number of commonly used types that are slightly different in the .NET Framework and the UWP.

segment.source: This enables the .NET Framework developer to work with familiar types instead of learning new ones.
segment.target: This enables the .NET Framework developer to work with familiar types instead of learning new ones.

segment.source: You can use these mapped .NET Framework types in the public interface of your component.
segment.target: You can use these mapped .NET Framework types in the public interface of your component.

segment.source: See "Declaring types in Windows Runtime Components" and "Passing Universal Windows Platform types to managed code" in Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic, and .NET Framework mappings of Windows Runtime types.
segment.target: See "Declaring types in Windows Runtime Components" and "Passing Universal Windows Platform types to managed code" in Creating Windows Runtime Components in C# and Visual Basic, and .NET Framework mappings of Windows Runtime types.

segment.source: Many of these mappings are interfaces.
segment.target: Many of these mappings are interfaces.

segment.source: For example, IListT maps to the UWP interface IVectorT.
segment.target: For example, IListT maps to the UWP interface IVectorT.

segment.source: If you use Liststring ( in Visual Basic) instead of IListstring as a parameter type, Winmdexp.exe provides a list of alternatives that includes all the mapped interfaces implemented by ListT.
segment.target: If you use Liststring ( in Visual Basic) instead of IListstring as a parameter type, Winmdexp.exe provides a list of alternatives that includes all the mapped interfaces implemented by ListT.

segment.source: If you use nested generic types, such as ListDictionaryint, string (List(Of Dictionary(Of Integer, String)) in Visual Basic), Winmdexp.exe offers choices for each level of nesting.
segment.target: If you use nested generic types, such as ListDictionaryint, string (List(Of Dictionary(Of Integer, String)) in Visual Basic), Winmdexp.exe offers choices for each level of nesting.

segment.source: These lists can become quite long.
segment.target: These lists can become quite long.

segment.source: In general, the best choice is the interface that is closest to the type.
segment.target: In general, the best choice is the interface that is closest to the type.

segment.source: For example, for Dictionaryint, string, the best choice is most likely IDictionaryint, string.
segment.target: For example, for Dictionaryint, string, the best choice is most likely IDictionaryint, string.

segment.source: Important JavaScript uses the interface that appears first in the list of interfaces that a managed type implements.
segment.target: Important JavaScript uses the interface that appears first in the list of interfaces that a managed type implements.

segment.source: For example, if you return Dictionaryint, string to JavaScript code, it appears as IDictionaryint, string no matter which interface you specify as the return type.
segment.target: For example, if you return Dictionaryint, string to JavaScript code, it appears as IDictionaryint, string no matter which interface you specify as the return type.

segment.source: This means that if the first interface doesn't include a member that appears on later interfaces, that member isn't visible to JavaScript.
segment.target: This means that if the first interface doesn't include a member that appears on later interfaces, that member isn't visible to JavaScript.

segment.source: Caution Avoid using the non-generic IList and IEnumerable interfaces if your component will be used by JavaScript.
segment.target: Caution Avoid using the non-generic IList and IEnumerable interfaces if your component will be used by JavaScript.

segment.source: These interfaces map to IBindableVector and IBindableIterator, respectively.
segment.target: These interfaces map to IBindableVector and IBindableIterator, respectively.

segment.source: They support binding for XAML controls, and are invisible to JavaScript.
segment.target: They support binding for XAML controls, and are invisible to JavaScript.

segment.source: JavaScript issues the run-time error "The function 'X' has an invalid signature and cannot be called."
segment.target: JavaScript issues the run-time error "The function 'X' has an invalid signature and cannot be called."

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1033
segment.target: WME1033

segment.source: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' of type '{2}'.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' of type '{2}'.

segment.source: '{2}' is not a valid Windows Runtime parameter type.
segment.target: '{2}' is not a valid Windows Runtime parameter type.

segment.source: WME1038
segment.target: WME1038

segment.source: Method '{0}' has a parameter of type '{1}' in its signature.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has a parameter of type '{1}' in its signature.

segment.source: Although this type is not a valid Windows Runtime type, it implements interfaces that are valid Windows Runtime types.
segment.target: Although this type is not a valid Windows Runtime type, it implements interfaces that are valid Windows Runtime types.

segment.source: Consider changing the method signature to use one of the following types instead: '{2}'.
segment.target: Consider changing the method signature to use one of the following types instead: '{2}'.

segment.source: WME1039
segment.target: WME1039

segment.source: Method '{0}' has a parameter of type '{1}' in its signature.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has a parameter of type '{1}' in its signature.

segment.source: Although this generic type is not a valid Windows Runtime type, the type or its generic parameters implement interfaces that are valid Windows Runtime types.
segment.target: Although this generic type is not a valid Windows Runtime type, the type or its generic parameters implement interfaces that are valid Windows Runtime types.

segment.source: Note For {2}, Winmdexp.exe appends a list of alternatives, such as "Consider changing the type 'System.Collections.Generic.ListT' in the method signature to one of the following types instead: 'System.Collections.Generic.IListT, System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyListT, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerableT'."
segment.target: Note For {2}, Winmdexp.exe appends a list of alternatives, such as "Consider changing the type 'System.Collections.Generic.ListT' in the method signature to one of the following types instead: 'System.Collections.Generic.IListT, System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyListT, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerableT'."

segment.source: WME1040
segment.target: WME1040

segment.source: Method '{0}' has a parameter of type '{1}' in its signature.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has a parameter of type '{1}' in its signature.

segment.source: Instead of using a managed Task type, use Windows.Foundation.IAsyncAction, Windows.Foundation.IAsyncOperation, or one of the other Windows Runtime async interfaces.
segment.target: Instead of using a managed Task type, use Windows.Foundation.IAsyncAction, Windows.Foundation.IAsyncOperation, or one of the other Windows Runtime async interfaces.

segment.source: The standard .NET await pattern also applies to these interfaces.
segment.target: The standard .NET await pattern also applies to these interfaces.

segment.source: Please see System.Runtime.InteropServices.WindowsRuntime.AsyncInfo for more information about converting managed task objects to Windows Runtime async interfaces.
segment.target: Please see System.Runtime.InteropServices.WindowsRuntime.AsyncInfo for more information about converting managed task objects to Windows Runtime async interfaces.

segment.source: Structures that contain fields of disallowed types
segment.target: Structures that contain fields of disallowed types

segment.source: In the UWP, a structure can contain only fields, and only structures can contain fields.
segment.target: In the UWP, a structure can contain only fields, and only structures can contain fields.

segment.source: Those fields must be public.
segment.target: Those fields must be public.

segment.source: Valid field types include enumerations, structures, and primitive types.
segment.target: Valid field types include enumerations, structures, and primitive types.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1060
segment.target: WME1060

segment.source: Structure '{0}' has field '{1}' of type '{2}'.
segment.target: Structure '{0}' has field '{1}' of type '{2}'.

segment.source: '{2}' is not a valid Windows Runtime field type.
segment.target: '{2}' is not a valid Windows Runtime field type.

segment.source: Each field in a Windows Runtime structure can only be UInt8, Int16, UInt16, Int32, UInt32, Int64, UInt64, Single, Double, Boolean, String, Enum, or itself a structure.
segment.target: Each field in a Windows Runtime structure can only be UInt8, Int16, UInt16, Int32, UInt32, Int64, UInt64, Single, Double, Boolean, String, Enum, or itself a structure.

segment.source: Restrictions on arrays in member signatures
segment.target: Restrictions on arrays in member signatures

segment.source: In the UWP, arrays in member signatures must be one-dimensional with a lower bound of 0 (zero).
segment.target: In the UWP, arrays in member signatures must be one-dimensional with a lower bound of 0 (zero).

segment.source: Nested array types such as ( in Visual Basic) are not allowed.
segment.target: Nested array types such as ( in Visual Basic) are not allowed.

segment.source: Note This restriction does not apply to arrays you use internally in your implementation.
segment.target: Note This restriction does not apply to arrays you use internally in your implementation.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1034
segment.target: WME1034

segment.source: Method '{0}' has an array of type '{1}' with non-zero lower bound in its signature.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has an array of type '{1}' with non-zero lower bound in its signature.

segment.source: Arrays in Windows Runtime method signatures must have a lower bound of zero.
segment.target: Arrays in Windows Runtime method signatures must have a lower bound of zero.

segment.source: WME1035
segment.target: WME1035

segment.source: Method '{0}' has a multi-dimensional array of type '{1}' in its signature.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has a multi-dimensional array of type '{1}' in its signature.

segment.source: Arrays in Windows Runtime method signatures must be one dimensional.
segment.target: Arrays in Windows Runtime method signatures must be one dimensional.

segment.source: WME1036
segment.target: WME1036

segment.source: Method '{0}' has a nested array of type '{1}' in its signature.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has a nested array of type '{1}' in its signature.

segment.source: Arrays in Windows Runtime method signatures cannot be nested.
segment.target: Arrays in Windows Runtime method signatures cannot be nested.

segment.source: Array parameters must specify whether array contents are readable or writable
segment.target: Array parameters must specify whether array contents are readable or writable

segment.source: In the UWP, parameters must be read-only or write-only.
segment.target: In the UWP, parameters must be read-only or write-only.

segment.source: Parameters cannot be marked ref (ByRef without the OutAttribute attribute in Visual Basic).
segment.target: Parameters cannot be marked ref (ByRef without the OutAttribute attribute in Visual Basic).

segment.source: This applies to the contents of arrays, so array parameters must indicate whether the array contents are read-only or write-only.
segment.target: This applies to the contents of arrays, so array parameters must indicate whether the array contents are read-only or write-only.

segment.source: The direction is clear for out parameters (ByRef parameter with the OutAttribute attribute in Visual Basic), but array parameters that are passed by value (ByVal in Visual Basic) must be marked.
segment.target: The direction is clear for out parameters (ByRef parameter with the OutAttribute attribute in Visual Basic), but array parameters that are passed by value (ByVal in Visual Basic) must be marked.

segment.source: See Passing arrays to a Windows Runtime Component.
segment.target: See Passing arrays to a Windows Runtime Component.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1101
segment.target: WME1101

segment.source: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is an array, and which has both {2} and {3}.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is an array, and which has both {2} and {3}.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime, the contents array parameters must be either readable or writable.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime, the contents array parameters must be either readable or writable.

segment.source: Please remove one of the attributes from '{1}'.
segment.target: Please remove one of the attributes from '{1}'.

segment.source: WME1102
segment.target: WME1102

segment.source: Method '{0}' has an output parameter '{1}' which is an array, but which has {2}.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has an output parameter '{1}' which is an array, but which has {2}.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime, the contents of output arrays are writable.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime, the contents of output arrays are writable.

segment.source: Please remove the attribute from '{1}'.
segment.target: Please remove the attribute from '{1}'.

segment.source: WME1103
segment.target: WME1103

segment.source: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is an array, and which has either a System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or a System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is an array, and which has either a System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or a System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime, array parameters must have either {2} or {3}.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime, array parameters must have either {2} or {3}.

segment.source: Please remove these attributes or replace them with the appropriate Windows Runtime attribute if necessary.
segment.target: Please remove these attributes or replace them with the appropriate Windows Runtime attribute if necessary.

segment.source: WME1104
segment.target: WME1104

segment.source: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is not an array, and which has either a {2} or a {3}.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is not an array, and which has either a {2} or a {3}.

segment.source: Windows Runtime does not support marking non-array parameters with {2} or {3}.
segment.target: Windows Runtime does not support marking non-array parameters with {2} or {3}.

segment.source: WME1105
segment.target: WME1105

segment.source: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' with a System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' with a System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.

segment.source: Windows Runtime does not support marking parameters with System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.
segment.target: Windows Runtime does not support marking parameters with System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.

segment.source: Please consider removing System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute and replace System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute with 'out' modifier instead.
segment.target: Please consider removing System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute and replace System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute with 'out' modifier instead.

segment.source: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' with a System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' with a System.Runtime.InteropServices.InAttribute or System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute.

segment.source: Windows Runtime only supports marking ByRef parameters with System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute, and does not support other usages of those attributes.
segment.target: Windows Runtime only supports marking ByRef parameters with System.Runtime.InteropServices.OutAttribute, and does not support other usages of those attributes.

segment.source: WME1106
segment.target: WME1106

segment.source: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is an array.
segment.target: Method '{0}' has parameter '{1}' which is an array.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime, the contents of array parameters must be either readable or writable.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime, the contents of array parameters must be either readable or writable.

segment.source: Please apply either {2} or {3} to '{1}'.
segment.target: Please apply either {2} or {3} to '{1}'.

segment.source: Member with a parameter named "value"
segment.target: Member with a parameter named "value"

segment.source: In the UWP, return values are considered to be output parameters, and the names of parameters must be unique.
segment.target: In the UWP, return values are considered to be output parameters, and the names of parameters must be unique.

segment.source: By default, Winmdexp.exe gives the return value the name "value".
segment.target: By default, Winmdexp.exe gives the return value the name "value".

segment.source: If your method has a parameter named "value", you will get error WME1092.
segment.target: If your method has a parameter named "value", you will get error WME1092.

segment.source: There are two ways to correct this:
segment.target: There are two ways to correct this:

segment.source: Give your parameter a name other than "value" (in property accessors, a name other than "returnValue").
segment.target: Give your parameter a name other than "value" (in property accessors, a name other than "returnValue").

segment.source: Use the ReturnValueNameAttribute attribute to change the name of the return value, as shown here:
segment.target: Use the ReturnValueNameAttribute attribute to change the name of the return value, as shown here:

segment.source: Note If you change the name of the return value, and the new name collides with the name of another parameter, you will get error WME1091.
segment.target: Note If you change the name of the return value, and the new name collides with the name of another parameter, you will get error WME1091.

segment.source: JavaScript code can access the output parameters of a method by name, including the return value.
segment.target: JavaScript code can access the output parameters of a method by name, including the return value.

segment.source: For an example, see the ReturnValueNameAttribute attribute.
segment.target: For an example, see the ReturnValueNameAttribute attribute.

segment.source: Error number
segment.target: Error number

segment.source: Message Text
segment.target: Message Text

segment.source: WME1091
segment.target: WME1091

segment.source: The method '\{0}' has the return value named '\{1}' which is the same as a parameter name.
segment.target: The method '\{0}' has the return value named '\{1}' which is the same as a parameter name.

segment.source: Windows Runtime method parameters and return value must have unique names.
segment.target: Windows Runtime method parameters and return value must have unique names.

segment.source: WME1092
segment.target: WME1092

segment.source: The method '\{0}' has a parameter named '\{1}' which is the same as the default return value name.
segment.target: The method '\{0}' has a parameter named '\{1}' which is the same as the default return value name.

segment.source: Consider using another name for the parameter or use the System.Runtime.InteropServices.WindowsRuntime.ReturnValueNameAttribute to explicitly specify the name of the return value.
segment.target: Consider using another name for the parameter or use the System.Runtime.InteropServices.WindowsRuntime.ReturnValueNameAttribute to explicitly specify the name of the return value.

segment.source: Note The default name is "returnValue" for property accessors and "value" for all other methods.
segment.target: Note The default name is "returnValue" for property accessors and "value" for all other methods.

segment.target: Related topics
